s.text: Proteins were then transferred to a PVDF membrane and Western blot analysis was performed.
The soluble portion of the homogenate was then transferred to a new tube for an additional centrifugation.

The complete disappearance of the upper band of the monomer doublet for the N604S mutation strongly suggests that the extracellular linker between the fifth transmembrane domain and the P-loop of VR1 is subject to N-linked glycosylation.
Since VR1 likely forms as a tetramer, the strong interaction we observed between pairs of subunits raises the question of whether this subunit interaction is involved in VR1 function.

Although it is tempting to conclude that the pH- and heat-resistent dimerization we observe with VR1 results from a covalent interaction, we cannot rule out other explanations such as strong hydrophobic interactions.
A current-voltage relation measured from these currents (Figure 1B) shows the pronounced outward rectification exhibited by VR1.
The solution bathing the extracellular surface of the patch was changed using a RSC-200 rapid solution changer (Molecular Kinetics, Pullman, WA).
